question: Question_07_(c)
statement:
In an experiment involving a bacteria population, $N(t)$ denotes the
size of the population (measured in thousands of individuals) as a
function of time, starting at $t=0$. The initial population is
$N(0) = N_{0}$.

c) What happens to the solution from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH103/April_2006/Question_07_(b)}{part
(b)} as $t\to 1$? Can you find an initial population $N_{0}$ for which
this problem doesn't occur for any time \emph{t}?
